page.title: 02GEOGRAPHY-HISTORY OF HORBURY
page.content: Horbury and South Osset are located on Millstone Grit hills overlooking the River Calder four miles South West of Wakefield.The Pennine Hills which dominate the north,are not as evident as further west and so present no problem to settlement or agriculture. The area was settled in the sixth and seventh centuries by people moving away from Waca's clearing (Wakefield)after local tribal arguments.Osla's camp (Osset) and the Marsh stockade settlement (Horbury) developed as a result.The site was chosen as it was protected by hills,had a spring and dominated a ford (Addingford)and bridging point (Horbury Bridge) across the Keld Dubra or Calder.The textile revolution led to Horbury and Ossett becoming towns in the nineteenth century and having their own civic buildings.
